Verb Conjugation in German

Just like in English, German verbs change depending on the subject (I, you, he, etc). This is called conjugation.

German Subject Pronouns

To conjugate verbs, you need to know the German words for I, you, he, we, they:

  • ich â€“ I
  • du â€“ you (informal)
  • er â€“ he
  • wir â€“ we
  • sie â€“ they

Example Verb: trinken (to drink)

To conjugate a verb in German, we remove the '-en' ending and add a new ending based on the pronoun. Letâ€™s see how it works for trinken:

  • ich â€“ trink + e = ich trinke (I drink)
  • du â€“ trink + st = du trinkst (you drink)
  • er â€“ trink + t = er trinkt (he drinks)
  • wir â€“ trink + en = wir trinken (we drink)
  • sie â€“ trink + en = sie trinken (they drink)

This rule works for most regular German verbs!

Notice the endings:

The verb stem is trink-. We just add different endings depending on the pronoun.


  • ich â†’ -e
  • du â†’ -st
  • er/sie/es â†’ -t
  • wir â†’ -en

More Verbs

These endings are used for most regular verbs too:

  • spielen (to play): ich spiele, du spielst, er spielt...
  • kochen (to cook): ich koche, du kochst, er kocht...
  • lernen (to learn): ich lerne, du lernst, er lernt...

Irregular Verbs

Some common verbs are irregular. For example:


  • essen (to eat): ich esse, du isst, er isst
  • sein (to be): ich bin, du bist, er ist...

We'll study these more in future lessons.
